questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right-sided lower abdominal pain for the past 8 weeks. During this period, the patient has had increased pain during activities such as walking and standing. She has no nausea, vomiting, or fever. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a nonpulsatile, palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament on the right side. The protrusion is palpable lateral to the location of the right inferior epigastric artery. Bulging is felt during the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Femoral hernias are relatively rare, accounting for approximately 5% of all hernias. They most commonly occur in female patients 40–70 years of age and can manifest as a painful, palpable groin protrusion associated with bulging during the Valsalva maneuver. However, femoral hernias are located below rather than above the inguinal ligament.

B) INCORRECT:

Rupture of an ovarian cyst can manifest with right-sided lower abdominal pain. However, the pain typically has a sudden onset following strenuous physical activity, and the abdomen is often tender to palpation. Moreover, ovarian cyst rupture does not manifest with a protrusion that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver.

C) INCORRECT:

Fallopian tube pregnancy, a form of ectopic pregnancy, usually manifests with lower abdominal pain. However, patients with ectopic pregnancy usually present with abdominal tenderness and guarding in the area of the ectopic pregnancy. Moreover, ectopic pregnancy does not manifest with a protrusion that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver.

D) CORRECT:

Inguinal hernias should be suspected in any patient with a palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver. Inguinal hernias are subdivided by anatomical location: indirect inguinal hernias protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, and direct inguinal hernias protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels. This patient has an indirect inguinal hernia, the most common type of hernia. Indirect inguinal hernias protrude through the inguinal canal from the deep to the superficial inguinal ring. Possible complications of hernias include incarcerated hernia and strangulated hernia. Patients with uncomplicated inguinal hernias should be scheduled for elective surgical repair. Patients with complicated inguinal hernias must undergo emergency surgical repair to minimize the likelihood of progression to gangrene of the hernial contents.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

E) INCORRECT:

Femoral artery aneurysms are usually asymptomatic but can manifest as a palpable mass in the inguinal region. However, the palpable mass of a femoral artery aneurysm is pulsatile and the condition is usually caused by atherosclerosis, for which this patient has no risk factors.

F) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias manifest with lower abdominal pain and a palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver. However, direct inguinal hernias protrude medial to the inferior epigastric vessels (i.e., within the Hesselbach triangle), not lateral. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias usually occur in men > 40 years of age and are uncommon in women.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the inguinal area, medial to the inferior epigastric blood vessels (sagittal plane; male patient)

1: internal oblique; 2: transversus abdominis; 3: external oblique aponeurosis; 4: transversalis fascia; 5: parietal peritoneum; 6: intestine; 7: inguinal ligament; 8: lacunar ligament; 9: superior pubic ramus; 10: spermatic cord

G) INCORRECT:

Strangulation is a potential complication of any type of hernia. It occurs when a loop of bowel becomes trapped in the herniated sack and the blood supply to the protruded bowel subsequently becomes constricted, leading to bowel ischemia. Acute strangulation is characterized by tenderness at the incarcerated site, followed by diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, but this patient has no such symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's protrusion is located outside the Hesselbach triangle.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in his left groin for the past hour. The pain began soon after he returned from a walk. He describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity and he vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had a swelling of the left groin for the past 2 months. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine, an albuterol inhaler, and a salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender bulge on the left side above the inguinal ligament that extends into the left scrotum; lying down does not reduce the swelling. Coughing does not make the swelling bulge further. The skin overlying the bulge is warm and erythematous. The abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Scattered rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical drainage is the treatment of choice for skin abscesses, e.g., of the groin or the scrotum. While abscesses may appear as a tender, erythematous swelling or bulging of the affected region, fluctuant red nodules with central purulent lesions are typically seen. This patient's 2-month history of inguinal swelling and concurrent symptoms of bowel obstruction make an acutely strangulated inguinal hernia the more likely diagnosis, for which surgical drainage is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is an appropriate treatment for epididymitis. While epididymitis manifests with swelling or bulging of the scrotum, it usually does not cause an acute onset of groin pain. Instead, epididymitis typically manifests with worsening scrotal pain as well as concurrent focal and systemic signs of infection, such as scotal erythema and fever. This patient has a strangulated inguinal hernia, for which antibiotics are not the treatment of choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Prior to the introduction of surgical hernia repair, taxis (manual reduction) was the treatment of choice for incarcerated hernias without concurrent bowel obstruction. It may still be attempted in patients with no evidence of strangulation who have contraindications for emergency surgery or who prefer to delay surgery. This patient presents with signs and symptoms of hernia strangulation (severe groin pain, erythema, and warmth overlying a groin bulge) and requires urgent surgical treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Open surgical repair is indicated for all patients with complicated inguinal hernias, i.e., incarcerated hernias with concurrent bowel obstruction or strangulation. This patient must undergo surgery within 4–6 hours of the onset of symptoms to avoid possible bowel loss secondary to tissue necrosis. In patients with complicated inguinal hernias, an open approach is preferred because it is easier to perform and associated with a decreased risk of bowel injury.

The most commonly used techniques for open surgical repair are Lichtenstein repair and Shouldice repair. During Lichtenstein repair, a synthetic mesh is implemented between the abdominal internal oblique muscle and the aponeurosis of the abdominal external oblique muscle. For the Shouldice procedure, the transverse fascia is doubled and fixated to the abdominal internal oblique muscle and transverse muscle at the inguinal ligament by suture (a nonmesh repair).

E) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical exploration of the testicle is indicated in patients with testicular torsion to prevent necrosis. While testicular torsion may also manifest with abrupt onset lower abdominal pain and vomiting, it does not explain the bulging of the groin above the inguinal ligament seen here. This patient has an acutely strangulated inguinal hernia, for which surgical exploration of the testicle is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic surgical repair is indicated for uncomplicated hernias and is usually carried out as an elective procedure. Because laparoscopic surgery is associated with a higher risk of bowel injury compared to other approaches, it should not be performed on patients with strangulated or incarcerated hernias and evidence of bowel obstruction. Furthermore, the placement of a synthetic mesh, which is required in laparoscopic hernia repair, should be avoided in patients at risk of surgical site infection, e.g., as a result of bowel perforation.
questions.hint: This patient's 2-month history of left groin swelling suggests an inguinal hernia, for which chronic cough (a symptom of COPD) is a risk factor. Acute onset of severe groin pain, vomiting, an inguinal bulge with overlying erythema and warmth, and a distended abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds indicate acute hernia strangulation with concurrent bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of a painless mass in his left groin that has been gradually increasing in size. Physical examination shows a 3x3-cm oval, nontender left inguinal mass and a fluctuant, painless left scrotal swelling that increases in size with coughing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Failure of processus vaginalis to close
Reduced fluid reabsorption at tunica vaginalis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The processus vaginalis descends anterior to the testis via the gubernaculum during embryonic development. Failure of this conduit to obliterate after testicular descent into the scrotum causes outpouching of the parietal peritoneum (and bowel) through the deep inguinal ring, the inguinal canal, and the superficial inguinal ring, leading to an indirect inguinal hernia. These hernias are located outside the Hesselbach triangle, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, and can manifest with a communicating hydrocele, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the left spermatic vein would lead to a left-sided varicocele. Although a varicocele can also manifest as a painless enlargement of the scrotum that increases in size with standing or coughing, an inguinal mass would not be expected.
Image Description:

Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.

C) INCORRECT:

Incomplete descent of the left testicle is seen in cryptorchidism, which can manifest with a mass in the inguinal region (between the external and internal inguinal ring). However, cryptorchidism is usually identified early in life and treated with orchiopexy around 6–18 months of age. It would therefore be unlikely in this 20-year-old patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Reduced fluid reabsorption in the tunica vaginalis can lead to a non-communicating hydrocele. Although this patient has clinical evidence of a hydrocele (a fluctuant painless swelling of the scrotum), the increase in swelling when coughing indicates that it is a communicating hydrocele, which implies a different mechanism.

E) INCORRECT:

Widening of the femoral ring is the mechanism underlying femoral hernias. Although femoral hernias manifest with an inguinal mass, the mass would be inferior to the inguinal ligament and would not cause a hydrocele. Furthermore, femoral hernias most commonly develop in older women (∼ 40–70 years of age).
Image Description:

Sagittal view of the male inguinal region at the level of the superior pubic ramus, medial to the epigastric vessels

There is a protruding hernial sac (comprised of the transversalis fascia and parietal peritoneum) below the inguinal ligament but above the pubic bone, which, in the example shown, contains intestine.

F) INCORRECT:

Weakening of the transversalis fascia can lead to a direct inguinal hernia. Although direct inguinal hernias also manifest with an inguinal mass, a hydrocele would not be expected. This type of hernia is located within the Hesselbach triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels, and only protrudes through the superficial (external) inguinal ring without involvement of the spermatic cord.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the inguinal area, medial to the inferior epigastric blood vessels (sagittal plane; male patient)

1: internal oblique; 2: transversus abdominis; 3: external oblique aponeurosis; 4: transversalis fascia; 5: parietal peritoneum; 6: intestine; 7: inguinal ligament; 8: lacunar ligament; 9: superior pubic ramus; 10: spermatic cord
questions.hint: In a young patient, inguinal swelling and signs of hydrocele (fluctuant, painless swelling of the scrotum that increases with coughing) suggest an indirect inguinal hernia.

questions.text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe groin pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports that he has had a groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining for the past 3 months, but he has not sought medical attention for it. Examination shows a nonreducible bulging mass of the left groin that is severely tender to palpation; the overlying skin is erythematous. Abdominal ultrasound shows protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely site of protrusion of the patient's groin mass?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The inguinal triangle (Hesselbach triangle) is the site of protrusion of direct inguinal hernias, as seen here. This triangle is bordered laterally by the inferior epigastric vessels, medially by the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis sheath, and inferiorly by the inguinal ligament, and covered anteriorly by the transversalis fascia, conjoined tendon, and the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. Unlike indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through both the superficial and deep inguinal rings and are, therefore, covered by all layers of the spermatic cord, direct inguinal hernias pass only through the superficial inguinal ring and, at this point, are only covered by the external spermatic fascia.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

B) INCORRECT:

The segment of the linea alba between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus is the site of protrusion of epigastric hernias, which cause swelling in the epigastric area rather than the groin.
Image Description:

Herniation of intraabdominal contents through the linea alba, between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus.

C) INCORRECT:

The hernia in this patient protrudes at a site that is lateral to the rectus abdominis muscle and covered by the transversalis fascia, conjoined tendon, and the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle; it does not protrude through the rectus abdominis.

D) INCORRECT:

The deep inguinal ring is the site of protrusion of indirect inguinal hernias, which manifest as a groin mass, like the one seen here. However, the deep inguinal ring is located lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels; this patient, however, has a hernia that protrudes medial to these vessels and does not pass through the deep inguinal ring.
Image Description:

Left illustration: anatomy of the inguinal canal and spermatic cord
The inguinal canal extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.
– Anterior wall: aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique muscle
– Posterior wall: the transversalis fascia
– Roof: the transversalis fascia, transversus abdominis muscles, and the internal oblique muscle
– Floor: inguinal ligament
– Content: in men, the ilioinguinal nerve, genitofemoral nerve, and spermatic cord; in women, the round ligament of the uterus
The spermatic cord contains the vas deferens, three arteries (testicular artery, artery to the ductus deferens, and cremasteric artery), the pampiniform plexus, and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Right illustration: the three coverings of the spermatic cord
From superficial to deep, the coverings are the external spermatic fascia (orange), cremasteric fascia (blue), and internal spermatic fascia (green).

E) INCORRECT:

The inferior lumbar triangle is the site of protrusion of inferior lumbar hernias, which cause swelling in the lumbar region rather than the groin.
Image Description:

Superior lumbar hernia (Grynfeltt hernia): herniation of intraabdominal contents through the superior lumbar triangle, the boundaries of which are the 12th rib, the erector spinae muscle, and the internal oblique muscle

Inferior lumbar hernia (Petit hernia): herniation of intraabdominal contents through the inferior lumbar triangle, the boundaries of which are the iliac crest, the latissimus dorsi, and the external oblique muscle

F) INCORRECT:

The femoral ring is the site of protrusion of femoral hernias, which manifest as a groin mass and are prone to strangulation, like the mass seen here. Femoral hernias, however, protrude inferior to the inguinal ligament and medial to the femoral vein rather than medial to the inferior epigastric vessels, and they typically occur in women rather than men.
Image Description:

Femoral hernia passes through the vascular lacuna (internal hernial orifice), below the inguinal ligament and usually medial to the femoral vein and runs through the femoral canal until it reaches the saphenous opening (external hernial orifice; approx. 2cm caudal).

The saphenous opening typically contains loose connective and fatty tissue as well as inguinal lymph nodes.

Due to the increased width of the female pelvis, and therefore larger vascular lacuna, femoral hernia occurs predominantly in women.
questions.hint: A groin swelling that worsens with standing, coughing, and straining is suggestive of a hernia, and severe pain with features of bowel obstruction (e.g., nausea, vomiting) indicates strangulation of this hernia. The type of hernia seen here typically occurs as a result of weakening of the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of a painless bulge in the right groin. His mother says that the bulge is only intermittently visible and increases in size with coughing. He was born via cesarean delivery at 32 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. He appears well. Growth and development are appropriate for age. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 40/min. Physical examination shows a 2 x 2-cm nontender right inguinal mass that is manually reducible with gradual pressure. Ultrasonography of the groin in supine position shows widening of the deep inguinal ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgery is indicated in patients with strangulated hernia or incarcerated hernia that cannot be reduced manually. Children with incarcerated hernias usually appear ill and may present with signs of mechanical bowel obstruction (e.g., pain, nausea, vomiting). This patient has an uncomplicated inguinal hernia that is manually reducible and does not require immediate surgical repair.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction can be a temporizing measure before definitive surgical repair of incarcerated inguinal hernias. While parental training on indications for obtaining medical care plays an essential role in the management of inguinal hernias in children, manual reduction should always be performed by a physician in a clinical setting! This procedure is contraindicated in patients with evidence of strangulation (e.g., erythema, warmth, or tenderness over the hernia) and extremely ill patients. Asymptomatic hernias, like the one seen here, do not require manual reduction.

C) CORRECT:

Surgical repair is indicated in all children with inguinal hernia. In asymptomatic patients, surgery should be performed within 14 days of diagnosis to avoid complications (e.g., incarcerated hernia). Therefore, emergency surgery is not required but referral should be obtained promptly. While waiting for elective surgery, parental training on signs and symptoms of incarceration is important because an incarcerated or strangulated hernia requires immediate action.

Indirect inguinal hernias are most common among male infants and infants who are born prematurely, as they mostly result from incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis during fetal development. Some hernias, despite being present since birth, do not become symptomatic until adulthood.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is indicated in patients with suspected inguinal hernia if ultrasonography findings are inconclusive. In this patient with characteristic findings (i.e., a nontender inguinal mass that increases in size with coughing and is manually reducible), a clinical diagnosis can be established, and additional imaging is therefore not needed.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in patients with communicating hydroceles, which may manifest with painless swelling, an increase in size with raised intraabdominal pressure, or manual reducibility. Hydroceles are typically located in the scrotum, and ultrasonography shows hypoechoic fluid. Reassurance and follow-up alone are not appropriate for an inguinal hernia.
questions.hint: An intermittent inguinal mass that increases in size with raised intraabdominal pressure is characteristic of an indirect inguinal hernia.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents for evaluation of a lump that he has felt in his groin area for the past 2 weeks. He first noticed it after returning from the gym, where he was lifting heavy weights. It has not changed in size since then. He does not recall any specific trauma or injury. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms regularly. He has been feeling well and has not had any urinary symptoms, rashes, genital lesions, penile discharge, fevers, or systemic symptoms.
On examination, the patient is afebrile and appears well. Abdominal examination is normal with no organomegaly. Genitourinary examination reveals a 1-cm solid, rubbery, mobile swelling near the inguinal canal; it is nontender with no overlying skin changes and does not change with the Valsalva maneuver. Scrotal examination reveals bilateral descended testicles that are nontender and without masses. There are no genital lesions or rashes. Cremasteric reflexes are intact bilaterally.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Causes of inguinal masses and swelling in adolescent boys include hernia (direct or indirect inguinal hernia, or femoral hernia), lymphadenopathy, lymphadenitis, hydrocele, undescended testicle, and testicular torsion. A thorough history and examination can usually identify the cause. In this case, the patient's history and examination suggest an isolated inguinal lymph node; he has no fever or systemic symptoms, and his physical examination is unremarkable other than the mass.

Observation is appropriate for an isolated, asymptomatic lymph node ≤1 cm of 2 weeks’ duration. Further evaluation is necessary for lymph nodes >3 cm, lymph nodes associated with systemic symptoms, generalized lymphadenopathy, lymphadenopathy >4 weeks’ duration, and lymphadenopathy in the supraclavicular area.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for an asymptomatic adolescent boy with an isolated, mobile, solid, rubbery, nontender 1-cm inguinal mass of 2 weeks’ duration is observation.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can be associated with inguinal lymphadenopathy but typically manifests with other symptoms as well, such as genital ulcers. This patient has no lesions to suggest HSV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound can be helpful for evaluating hernias and subcutaneous masses. However, inguinal and femoral hernias are typically diagnosed on physical examination, and this patient’s mobile mass is rubbery and solid, more consistent with a lymph node than a hernia. A hernia may manifest as an intermittent swelling or bulging. Examination may reveal a reducible mass at the inguinal canal that becomes more prominent with the Valsalva maneuver (this patient’s does not), or there may be no mass at all. If no obvious hernia is evident on physical examination, surgical intervention is unlikely to be warranted, even if ultrasound reveals a tiny hernia.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral is indicated if testicular torsion or hernia is suspected. Torsion typically manifests with acute testicular pain. Classic examination findings include a high-riding, tender, swollen testicle with absent cremasteric reflex.

E) INCORRECT:

Testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea is appropriate in the evaluation of possible sexually transmitted infections. In males, these infections may be asymptomatic or may manifest as penile discharge with or without dysuria. Patients who test positive for chlamydia should receive either azithromycin 1 gram by mouth in a single dose or doxycycline 100 mg by mouth twice daily for 7 days. Empiric antibiotic treatment is not indicated in this patient, who has no other signs or symptoms of a sexually transmitted infection (such as dysuria or penile discharge).

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of right-sided lower abdominal pain for the past 8 weeks. During this period, the patient has had increased pain during activities such as walking and standing. She has no nausea, vomiting, or fever. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a nonpulsatile, palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament on the right side. The protrusion is palpable lateral to the location of the right inferior epigastric artery. Bulging is felt during the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Femoral hernias are relatively rare, accounting for approximately 5% of all hernias. They most commonly occur in female patients 40–70 years of age and can manifest as a painful, palpable groin protrusion associated with bulging during the Valsalva maneuver. However, femoral hernias are located below rather than above the inguinal ligament.

B) INCORRECT:

Rupture of an ovarian cyst can manifest with right-sided lower abdominal pain. However, the pain typically has a sudden onset following strenuous physical activity, and the abdomen is often tender to palpation. Moreover, ovarian cyst rupture does not manifest with a protrusion that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver.

C) INCORRECT:

Fallopian tube pregnancy, a form of ectopic pregnancy, usually manifests with lower abdominal pain. However, patients with ectopic pregnancy usually present with abdominal tenderness and guarding in the area of the ectopic pregnancy. Moreover, ectopic pregnancy does not manifest with a protrusion that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver.

D) CORRECT:

Inguinal hernias should be suspected in any patient with a palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver. Inguinal hernias are subdivided by anatomical location: indirect inguinal hernias protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, and direct inguinal hernias protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels. This patient has an indirect inguinal hernia, the most common type of hernia. Indirect inguinal hernias protrude through the inguinal canal from the deep to the superficial inguinal ring. Possible complications of hernias include incarcerated hernia and strangulated hernia. Patients with uncomplicated inguinal hernias should be scheduled for elective surgical repair. Patients with complicated inguinal hernias must undergo emergency surgical repair to minimize the likelihood of progression to gangrene of the hernial contents.

Key learning point: An indirect inguinal hernia presents as a groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, and bulges with increased intra-abdominal pressure.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias manifest with lower abdominal pain and a palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver. However, direct inguinal hernias protrude medial to the inferior epigastric vessels (i.e., within the Hesselbach triangle), not lateral. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias usually occur in men > 40 years of age and are uncommon in women.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the inguinal area, medial to the inferior epigastric blood vessels (sagittal plane; male patient)

1: internal oblique; 2: transversus abdominis; 3: external oblique aponeurosis; 4: transversalis fascia; 5: parietal peritoneum; 6: intestine; 7: inguinal ligament; 8: lacunar ligament; 9: superior pubic ramus; 10: spermatic cord
questions.hint: This patient's protrusion is located outside the Hesselbach triangle.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in his left groin for the past hour. He describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity and he vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had a swelling of the left groin for the past 2 months. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Examination shows a tender bulge on the left side above the inguinal ligament that extends into the left scrotum; lying down does not reduce the swelling. Coughing does not make the swelling bulge further. The skin overlying the bulge is warm and erythematous. The abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is an appropriate treatment for epididymitis. While epididymitis manifests with swelling or bulging of the scrotum, it usually does not cause an acute onset of groin pain. Instead, epididymitis typically manifests with worsening scrotal pain as well as concurrent focal and systemic signs of infection, such as scotal erythema and fever. This patient has a strangulated inguinal hernia, for which antibiotics are not the treatment of choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Prior to the introduction of surgical hernia repair, manual reduction was the treatment of choice for incarcerated hernias without concurrent bowel obstruction. It may still be attempted in patients with no evidence of strangulation who have contraindications for emergency surgery or who prefer to delay surgery. This patient presents with signs and symptoms of hernia strangulation (severe groin pain, erythema, and warmth overlying a groin bulge) and requires urgent surgical treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Open surgical repair is indicated for all patients with complicated inguinal hernias, i.e., incarcerated hernias with concurrent bowel obstruction or strangulation. This patient must undergo surgery within 4–6 hours of the onset of symptoms to avoid possible bowel loss secondary to tissue necrosis. In patients with complicated inguinal hernias, an open approach is preferred because it is easier to perform and associated with a decreased risk of bowel injury.

The most commonly used techniques for open surgical repair are Lichtenstein repair and Shouldice repair. During Lichtenstein repair, a synthetic mesh is implemented between the abdominal internal oblique muscle and the aponeurosis of the abdominal external oblique muscle. For the Shouldice procedure, the transverse fascia is doubled and fixated to the abdominal internal oblique muscle and transverse muscle at the inguinal ligament by suture (a nonmesh repair).

D) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical exploration of the testicle is indicated in patients with testicular torsion to prevent necrosis. While testicular torsion may also manifest with abrupt onset lower abdominal pain and vomiting, it does not explain the bulging of the groin above the inguinal ligament seen here. This patient has an acutely strangulated inguinal hernia, for which surgical exploration of the testicle is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic surgical repair is indicated for uncomplicated hernias and is usually carried out as an elective procedure. Because laparoscopic surgery is associated with a higher risk of bowel injury compared to other approaches, it should not be performed on patients with strangulated or incarcerated hernias and evidence of bowel obstruction. Furthermore, the placement of a synthetic mesh, which is required in laparoscopic hernia repair, should be avoided in patients at risk of surgical site infection, e.g., as a result of bowel perforation.
questions.hint: This patient's 2-month history of left groin swelling suggests an inguinal hernia, for which chronic cough (a symptom of COPD) is a risk factor. Acute onset of severe groin pain, vomiting, an inguinal bulge with overlying erythema and warmth, and a distended abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds indicate acute hernia strangulation with concurrent bowel obstruction.

questions.text:
An 8-week-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with a two-hour history of a painful swelling in his right scrotum extending into the inguinal region. The mother reports that the swelling has been present intermittently but now remains constantly visible and cannot be pushed back in. He is afebrile, and vital signs are stable. Examination shows a tender and tense scrotum, and the right testis cannot be palpated separately from the swelling.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion typically presents with acute scrotal pain and a high-riding, firm testis without an inguinal component. The history of intermittent reducibility and swelling extending into the inguinal region suggests a hernia rather than torsion, which involves twisting of the spermatic cord within the scrotum.

B) INCORRECT:

Epididymo-orchitis, an infection of the epididymis and testis, is rare in infants and more common in older children with risk factors for infections. The absence of fever and systemic signs, along with the history of intermittent swelling and irreducibility, suggests a mechanical issue rather than an infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroceles present as painless, fluctuant scrotal swellings that transilluminate and may vary in size. The acutely painful, tense, and irreducible mass extending into the inguinal region is inconsistent with a hydrocele, which typically does not cause marked discomfort or prevent palpation of the testis.

D) CORRECT:

Incarcerated inguinal hernia in pediatric patients is often due to a patent processus vaginalis, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the inguinal canal and scrotum. The history of intermittent swelling that becomes persistently visible and non-reducible suggests entrapment. The clinical findings of a tender, tense swelling extending from the inguinal region into the scrotum, with the inability to palpate the testis separately, indicate displacement and entrapment of structures like bowel loops. This condition can compromise blood flow if untreated. The patient's age, anatomical predisposition, and transformation from reducible to fixed swelling support this diagnosis.

Key learning point: In infants, a firm, tender, irreducible scrotal lump extending to the groin with an impalpable testis is suggestive of an incarcerated inguinal hernia.

questions.text:
A 3-week-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a persistent swelling in the right side of his scrotum noted since birth. The swelling remains unchanged when he cries and does not disappear with gentle pressure. On examination, the scrotal mass is non-tender and does not transilluminate. He is feeding well and has normal vital signs.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicocele, resulting from dilated pampiniform venous plexus, is seen in older children or adolescents. It presents as a soft, compressible mass with a 'bag of worms' consistency, increasing with Valsalva maneuvers. The described mass is present since birth, unchanged with crying, and does not transilluminate, inconsistent with varicocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital hydroceles typically present as fluid collections within the tunica vaginalis that transilluminate. They may change with intra-abdominal pressure variations, such as crying. The described scrotal mass does not transilluminate and remains unchanged with crying, inconsistent with a hydrocele.

C) CORRECT:

Inguinal hernia in pediatric patients occurs due to a patent processus vaginalis, allowing peritoneal contents to protrude into the inguinal canal and scrotum. The non-transilluminating, persistent scrotal swelling suggests tissue rather than fluid, consistent with herniated abdominal contents. The mass's unchanging nature, even with maneuvers affecting fluid-filled structures, supports this diagnosis. Male infants are particularly susceptible due to delayed closure of the processus vaginalis. Early identification is crucial to prevent complications like incarceration and strangulation, necessitating timely surgical intervention.

Key learning point: A non-tender, non-reducible scrotal mass in an infant that does not transilluminate is most suggestive of an inguinal hernia.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion presents with acute scrotal pain, swelling, and tenderness due to compromised blood flow. The described mass is non-tender, present since birth, and unchanged with crying, contrasting with the acute, painful presentation of torsion.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old healthy man presents with bilateral groin protrusions noticed three months ago. He is an avid runner and experiences intermittent discomfort while exercising. He wishes to resume his usual workouts as soon as possible and seeks a surgical solution. Physical examination shows palpable, reducible swellings in each inguinal region without signs of trapped bowel. Vital signs and laboratory results are normal.
Which of the following surgical approaches is most appropriate for his condition?

choices.text: Bilateral laparoscopic tension-free repair with mesh
Open tension-free mesh repair on each side in separate procedures

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bilateral laparoscopic tension-free repair with mesh is ideal for this active patient with bilateral inguinal hernias. This minimally invasive approach allows simultaneous repair, providing a clear view of the inguinal anatomy and minimizing tissue trauma. The use of mesh reinforces the myopectineal orifice, reducing recurrence rates. Benefits include reduced postoperative pain, faster recovery, and earlier return to activities, aligning with the patient's desire to resume exercise quickly.

Key learning point: Laparoscopic repair with mesh is often preferred for bilateral inguinal hernias in young, active individuals due to less postoperative pain, quicker recovery, and the ability to address both hernias simultaneously.

B) INCORRECT:

Open tension-free mesh repair is effective for inguinal hernias but performing separate procedures for bilateral hernias prolongs recovery and exposes the patient to multiple anesthetic events. This approach does not meet the patient's need for a quick return to activity.

C) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic repair without mesh lacks the tension-free reinforcement provided by mesh, increasing recurrence risk. Mesh-based repairs are preferred in adults to reduce recurrence, especially in active individuals. Non-mesh repairs are typically reserved for pediatric cases or specific contraindications.

D) INCORRECT:

Watchful waiting is suitable for asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic hernias, especially in older patients or those with comorbidities. This young, active patient experiences discomfort during exercise and seeks surgical resolution, making watchful waiting inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with a gradually enlarging right groin bulge. He had a procedure for a similar problem on the same side one year ago. He experiences discomfort after prolonged standing but has no systemic symptoms. He is otherwise healthy. Physical examination reveals a reducible soft mass near the original incision. Imaging confirms a defect in the same region. He seeks definitive treatment.
Which of the following surgical approaches is the most appropriate?

choices.text: No operative intervention until symptoms worsen
Open anterior repair with another prosthetic graft
Minimally invasive approach to place prosthetic material
Re-explore the previous incision and close the defect with sutures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonoperative management is inappropriate for recurrent hernias with discomfort. Imaging confirms a defect, and recurrence after prior repair increases the risk of complications like incarceration. Surgical repair is indicated to prevent further issues. The patient's desire for definitive treatment also supports operative management rather than delaying intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Open anterior repair with a prosthetic graft is suitable for primary hernias but poses challenges in recurrent cases due to scar tissue and altered anatomy. Reentering the same surgical field increases the risk of nerve and vascular injury and complicates dissection. Placing another graft in a previously operated area may increase infection and adhesion risks.

C) CORRECT:

Recurrent inguinal hernias after previous open repair are best managed with a minimally invasive approach, such as transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) or totally extraperitoneal (TEP) repair. This technique allows access to the preperitoneal space without encountering scar tissue from prior surgery, facilitating tension-free placement of prosthetic mesh. The laparoscopic approach provides a comprehensive view of the inguinal region, aiding in the identification of any additional hernias. It also reduces the risk of nerve injury and vascular complications associated with scar tissue. Clinical evidence supports this approach for recurrent hernias due to reduced postoperative pain, faster recovery, and lower recurrence rates.

Key learning point: In cases of recurrent inguinal hernia, laparoscopic mesh repair is often preferred due to better visualization and less invasiveness compared to open repair.

D) INCORRECT:

Re-exploring the previous incision and closing the defect with sutures is not ideal for recurrent hernias. Scar tissue from prior surgery compromises tissue integrity, making suture repair less effective and increasing recurrence risk. Scar tissue also obscures anatomical planes, raising the risk of complications. Tension-free repair with mesh is preferred for recurrent hernias to provide a durable closure.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to your clinic with right-sided lower abdominal pain for the past 8 weeks. She reports that the pain worsens with activities such as walking and standing. She has not experienced nausea, vomiting, or fever. On examination, her abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a nonpulsatile, palpable groin protrusion above the right inguinal ligament, lateral to the right inferior epigastric artery. The bulge becomes more prominent during the Valsalva maneuver. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Femoral hernias are relatively rare, accounting for approximately 5% of all hernias. They most commonly occur in female patients 40–70 years of age and can manifest as a painful, palpable groin protrusion associated with bulging during the Valsalva maneuver. However, femoral hernias are located below rather than above the inguinal ligament.

B) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias manifest with lower abdominal pain and a palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver. However, direct inguinal hernias protrude medial to the inferior epigastric vessels (i.e., within the Hesselbach triangle), not lateral. Moreover, direct inguinal hernias usually occur in men > 40 years of age and are uncommon in women.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of an ovarian cyst can manifest with right-sided lower abdominal pain. However, the pain typically has a sudden onset following strenuous physical activity, and the abdomen is often tender to palpation. Moreover, ovarian cyst rupture does not manifest with a protrusion that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver.

D) INCORRECT:

Fallopian tube pregnancy, a form of ectopic pregnancy, usually manifests with lower abdominal pain. However, patients with ectopic pregnancy usually present with abdominal tenderness and guarding in the area of the ectopic pregnancy. Moreover, ectopic pregnancy does not manifest with a protrusion that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver.

E) CORRECT:

Inguinal hernias should be suspected in any patient with a palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament that bulges during the Valsalva maneuver. Inguinal hernias are subdivided by anatomical location: indirect inguinal hernias protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, and direct inguinal hernias protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels. This patient has an indirect inguinal hernia, the most common type of hernia. Indirect inguinal hernias protrude through the inguinal canal from the deep to the superficial inguinal ring. Possible complications of hernias include incarcerated hernia and strangulated hernia. Patients with uncomplicated inguinal hernias should be scheduled for elective surgical repair. Patients with complicated inguinal hernias must undergo emergency surgical repair to minimize the likelihood of progression to gangrene of the hernial contents.

Key learning point: An indirect inguinal hernia presents as a groin bulge above the inguinal ligament, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, and becomes more prominent with increased intra-abdominal pressure.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.
questions.hint: This patient's protrusion is located outside the Hesselbach triangle.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-hour history of severe right groin pain. He has a known inguinal hernia that is usually reducible. On examination, there is a firm, tender mass in the right inguinal region that cannot be easily reduced. The overlying skin appears normal. Vital signs are normal, and he has no nausea or vomiting. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While surgical consultation will ultimately be needed, attempting manual reduction first is appropriate in incarcerated hernias without signs of strangulation. Manual reduction can serve as a temporizing measure and may avoid the need for urgent surgery if successful.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has an incarcerated hernia that requires urgent intervention, not discharge, because incarcerated hernias can progress to strangulation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has an incarcerated hernia without signs of strangulation (normal overlying skin, normal vital signs, no systemic symptoms), for which manual reduction is appropriate as a temporizing measure before surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

Admission for observation is appropriate after successful reduction. However, manual reduction should be attempted first as a temporizing measure in incarcerated hernias without signs of strangulation before proceeding to admission or surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are indicated for strangulated hernias or if there are signs of infection. This patient has normal overlying skin and vital signs, with no evidence of strangulation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of chronic constipation presents with a 4-hour history of severe right groin pain and vomiting. He reports that the groin mass has been present for years but was previously reducible. Physical examination shows a tense, irreducible inguinal mass with overlying skin that is warm and erythematous. Vital signs are BP, 130/80; P, 105; R, 18; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Apply ice pack and attempt manual reduction
Insert nasogastric tube and admit for observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although CT may assist with surgical planning, the diagnosis of a strangulated hernia is primarily clinical, and imaging should not delay urgent surgical consultation.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction is contraindicated if there are signs of strangulation. Warm, erythematous skin overlying the hernia suggests a compromised blood supply to the hernial contents, making reduction dangerous because it risks introducing necrotic tissue into the abdominal cavity.

C) INCORRECT:

Ice application followed by attempted reduction is contraindicated in strangulated hernias. Warm, erythematous skin indicates tissue compromise, and attempting manual reduction risks introducing ischemic or necrotic bowel into the abdominal cavity, potentially causing peritonitis or sepsis.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has classic signs of a strangulated hernia, including sudden severe pain, irreducible mass, warm erythematous overlying skin, and systemic symptoms. Strangulated hernias are surgical emergencies that require immediate surgical consultation because intestinal infarction can occur within 6 hours.

E) INCORRECT:

Observation is inappropriate for strangulated hernias. An irreducible hernia with warm, erythematous overlying skin suggests a compromised blood supply to hernial contents, which requires immediate surgical intervention to prevent bowel necrosis and subsequent complications. Nasogastric tube placement may be considered, but only as supportive care after surgical consultation is obtained.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male construction worker comes to the office with a one-month history of a painless bulge in his right groin. He reports the bulge is more prominent after heavy lifting. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. On examination, a soft, reducible mass is felt in the right inguinal region. When the patient stands and coughs, the mass protrudes through the external inguinal ring and extends into the scrotum. The mass can be easily reduced back into the abdominal cavity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A direct inguinal hernia is an acquired condition where abdominal contents protrude through a weakness in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal (Hesselbach's triangle), medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. While they typically manifest as a reducible groin bulge, direct hernias do not extend into the scrotum. Furthermore, direct hernias predominantly affect older men.

B) INCORRECT:

Inguinal lymphadenopathy presents as a firm, often tender mass in the groin. Enlarged lymph nodes are not reducible and do not change in size with Valsalva maneuvers or changes in body position, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A femoral hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents through the femoral ring, located inferior to the inguinal ligament. While it can present as a groin bulge, its location is distinct from an inguinal hernia. The mass described follows the path of the spermatic cord through the inguinal canal, which is anatomically inconsistent with a femoral hernia.

D) CORRECT:

An indirect inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents protrude through the deep (internal) inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. This is typically caused by a congenital failure of the processus vaginalis to close. The hernia sac then travels along the inguinal canal with the spermatic cord and can emerge from the superficial (external) inguinal ring, potentially descending into the scrotum. This patient's presentation of a reducible groin mass that follows the path of the spermatic cord when intra-abdominal pressure increases is the classic description. Indirect hernias are the most common type of hernia in all age groups and sexes, especially in young men.

E) INCORRECT:

A hydrocele of the cord is a cystic collection of fluid along the spermatic cord. Although it presents as a mass in the inguinal region, it is typically irreducible and does not change in size with coughing or supine positioning. The patient's mass is reducible and becomes prominent with increased intra-abdominal pressure, which is characteristic of a hernia, not a fluid-filled cyst.
questions.hint: The Valsalva maneuver typically produces an expansile cough impulse in this condition.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man with a history of a reducible left inguinal hernia presents to the emergency department with 12 hours of severe, colicky abdominal pain, nausea, and bilious vomiting. He has not passed stool or flatus for the past day. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate is 115/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. There is a tender, erythematous, and firm 6-cm mass in the left inguinal region that cannot be reduced. An upright abdominal radiograph demonstrates dilated small bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention?

choices.text: Urgent CT scan with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction can be attempted for an incarcerated hernia that is not tender and shows no signs of strangulation. However, this patient's hernia is tender and erythematous, and he has systemic signs of toxicity (fever, tachycardia), all of which are strong indicators of strangulation. Attempting to reduce a strangulated hernia is contraindicated because it can push necrotic bowel back into the peritoneal cavity, leading to perforation and peritonitis.

B) CORRECT:

Strangulated hernia is a life-threatening surgical emergency that requires immediate intervention to prevent bowel necrosis, perforation, and sepsis. An emergent exploratory laparotomy is necessary to assess the viability of the entrapped bowel, resect any non-viable segments, and repair the hernia. Any delay for further imaging or non-operative management significantly increases morbidity and mortality.

C) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic hernia repair is a common procedure for elective or uncomplicated inguinal hernias. In the setting of an acute small bowel obstruction with suspected strangulation, a laparoscopic approach is generally not preferred. The massively dilated bowel loops would severely limit the operative view, and it is more difficult to assess bowel viability and perform a potential bowel resection laparoscopically in this emergent situation.

D) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube decompression is an important component of the initial management of a small bowel obstruction to relieve distension and prevent aspiration. However, observation is inappropriate here, as delaying further intervention risks bowel infarction and perforation.

E) INCORRECT:

While a CT scan is often used to diagnose and characterize a small bowel obstruction, it is not necessary in this case. The diagnosis of a strangulated inguinal hernia causing obstruction is clear based on the history and physical examination findings. Obtaining a CT scan would unnecessarily delay definitive, time-sensitive treatment for a patient with signs of strangulation and hemodynamic instability.
questions.hint: The combination of a tender, non-reducible hernia, systemic signs (e.g., fever, tachycardia), and features of small bowel obstruction is suggestive of a strangulated inguinal hernia.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of severe, colicky abdominal pain, nausea, and bilious vomiting. She has not passed flatus or stool since yesterday. She has a known right groin bulge that has become acutely painful and hard. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), heart rate is 118/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a distended, tympanitic abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. There is a tender, erythematous, non-reducible 4-cm mass in her right groin inferior to the inguinal ligament. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm³ and a lactate level of 4.2 mmol/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical intervention?

choices.text: Creation of a diverting ostomy proximal to the obstruction
Manual reduction of the hernia followed by elective repair in 24–48 hours
Immediate open hernia repair with mesh placement
Exploratory laparotomy with bowel resection if non-viable, followed by hernia repair
Laparoscopic hernia repair with mesh placement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A diverting ostomy is a procedure to decompress the bowel proximal to an obstruction, but it does not address the underlying cause. In this case, the cause is a strangulated hernia containing ischemic bowel. Leaving the necrotic bowel segment in situ while creating an ostomy would not resolve the primary problem and would inevitably lead to perforation, peritonitis, and sepsis.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction is appropriate only for incarcerated hernias without evidence of strangulation. Attempting to reduce this hernia is contraindicated due to the high likelihood of bowel necrosis, as indicated by this patient's systemic signs and elevated lactate. Forcibly pushing a non-viable segment of bowel back into the abdomen can lead to perforation, peritonitis, and fulminant sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although an immediate hernia repair is necessary, this surgery is incomplete and potentially harmful. Furthermore, placing synthetic mesh is contraindicated in a contaminated or potentially contaminated surgical field, as is the case with a strangulated bowel, due to the high risk of infection.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a strangulated femoral hernia causing a complicated small bowel obstruction. Fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, and elevated lactate are critical signs of bowel ischemia or necrosis. The primary surgical priority is to assess bowel viability. An exploratory laparotomy provides the necessary exposure to inspect the incarcerated bowel. If the bowel is found to be non-viable (necrotic), a bowel resection with anastomosis is required to prevent perforation and sepsis. After the bowel has been addressed, the hernia defect is repaired. This sequence correctly prioritizes the life-threatening complication of strangulation over the hernia repair itself.

E) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic repair is a viable option for elective or uncomplicated hernias. However, in a patient with a strangulated hernia, significant bowel distention, and hemodynamic instability, an alternative approach is often preferred for better control. Additionally, placing synthetic mesh is contraindicated in a contaminated field due to the high risk of infection from the ischemic bowel.
questions.hint: A non-reducible groin mass with signs of small bowel obstruction and systemic findings such as fever, leukocytosis, and elevated lactate strongly suggests bowel strangulation.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with a painless bulge in the right groin that has gradually increased in size over the past few months. He has no significant past medical history. The bulge becomes more prominent when coughing or standing for prolonged periods. Examination reveals a non-tender mass in the right inguinal region with a positive cough impulse, distinct from the testis, and easily reducible.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Indirect inguinal hernias manifest as a groin bulge that becomes more prominent with increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or standing. They are common in young males and result from a patent processus vaginalis, allowing abdominal contents to protrude through the deep inguinal ring and follow the inguinal canal. The mass is typically reducible and separate from the testis, as it follows the spermatic cord's pathway. These features align with the clinical presentation of a painless, reducible groin mass with a positive cough impulse.

Key learning point: A positive cough impulse in a groin swelling that is separable from the testis is indicative of an indirect inguinal hernia.
Image Description:

Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cord

Indirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

B) INCORRECT:

Femoral hernias occur below the inguinal ligament and are more common in older women. The described mass is in the inguinal region, distinct from the testis, and easily reducible, aligning more with an inguinal hernia. These features, along with the patient's demographic, make a femoral hernia unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

A hydrocele is a fluid collection around the testis, presenting as a painless scrotal swelling that transilluminates. It is confined to the scrotum and does not exhibit a positive cough impulse or reducibility, unlike the described inguinal mass, which is distinct from the testis and related to intra-abdominal pressure changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct inguinal hernias occur due to weakness in the inguinal canal floor within Hesselbach’s triangle, typically in older individuals. The patient is an 18-year-old male, where indirect hernias are more common. The reducible mass with a positive cough impulse and distinct from the testis suggests an indirect hernia, not the medially confined direct type.
